segments.text: when you had been trained as an artillery officer?
Well, communications was a major part of training of any artillery officer because the artillery cannot function without good communications.
Actually, we were very proud of the fact that many times the entire division depended on artillery communications for a commanding general to be able to communicate with his troops.
So there's a lot of emphasis on wire and radio for any artillery officer's training.
I had kind of an aptitude for that, and some love of it.
So for instance, as a reconnaissance officer, that's a major responsibility, being able to communicate working with wire and radio.
So it wasn't a neurological assignment at all.
and I served then as communication officer and commander of headquarters battery until after we'd been in combat for 30 days and then I was moved into the fire direction center.
That was the second time I'd been assigned as assistant S3 operations officer.
So in other words, then you were the assistant commander?
No, not assistant commander, assistant operations officer.
That's a fire direction officer.
The person that does that has a job running the fire direction center.
Usually a person that does that has to be fairly good in mathematics because it's pretty much a mathematical exercise.
I like that.
How did you like your first command?
Well, there were mixed emotions about that.
Headquarters battery commander is not a good command job because while you're commander,
On the headquarters staff, you have to take care of all of the officers that rank higher than you do.
And most of the men in a headquarters battery are assigned to a section commanded by an officer that outranks the headquarters battery commander.
So it's not the best command job there is.
Still, I like the command job.
and was able to get along with the higher ranking officers.
And how many men did you have under your control?
Oh, I think headquarters battery had about 120 men in those days.
And as far as headquarters battery is concerned, what you do is, well explain exactly.
The tactical job, it was combined with communication officers.
So the tactical responsibility of the headquarters battery commander was communications.

And the administrative responsibility was, of course, supplies, rations, command of the troops, taking care of the administrative matters related to the troops that manned the different sections of the headquarters.
How were you doing on D-Day?
I was sitting off the coast of Normandy in a Liberty ship.
I was there in the greatest spectacle in the world, I guess.
There were ships as far as you could see in any direction, most of them flying barrage balloons.
There was still the firing from our warships, our destroyers against shore batteries off Omaha Beach.
There were the landing parties going in.
There was the overhead cover during the daylight hours from the American and British aircraft.
At dusk,
You could look in one direction and see airplanes returning to England and the other direction see the German planes coming in, dive bombers, that sort of thing.
They dominated the scene at night.
And the British and American planes dominated the daylight hours.
But it was one more spectacle.
And how many men did you have on your Liberty ship?
Well, there were two batteries on there, so there'd be about 250 men.
And you were waiting to go ashore after the second wave then?
That's right.
First the infantry, and then you?
Well, the first two divisions were assault troops.
These were the 1st and 9th Division of the 5th Corps, and the 2nd Division was follow-up troops.
So the 2nd Division landed on B-plus-1 infantry artillery, went between the 1st and 9th Divisions and attacked to the south.
And at that time, the 1st and 9th Divisions had won the battle of resistance of the troops
were stationed in that area, there wasn't really anything much between us and Berlin of any great organized bases.
So our initial, initially we had no resistance, but very soon the Germans threw in reinforcements, attacked us from the flank,
We got strung out about nine miles beyond the 1st and 9th Divisions, so pretty well along the flanks.
Our 38th Infantry Regiment took very heavy casualties, and we had to pull back and consolidate positions from the dominant terrain, which was a hill 192 meters high.
It's called Hill 192 that's overlooking St. Louis.
So we pulled back and consolidated positions,
held in that position for six weeks while the supplies caught up and built up for a further attack.
Are you under Bradley then?
Yes, we were under Bradley, who later of course was given an army group.
He was Corps Commander at that time as I recall.
Patton was building up for the breakout
troops, of course, after the Battle of St. Louis.

Patton took his armored divisions and made the famous raids on down into southern France and bottled up German troops into some of the seaport areas and ran wild for a while after he broke through the primary resistance right there.
But we sat in one position for six weeks after we got in there and pulled back while there was a build up of supplies and additional troops.
We were about nine miles in from the beach.
In other words, you went in on D plus one then?
D plus one.
Did you feel that you were part of a great historical event?
I suppose so.
Our troops had been training for this for a long time.
We were ready to engage in combat.
We were confident, professional soldiers at that time.
That didn't mean we weren't scared, you know.
We weren't insane when we got into
shelling and bombings and all.
We suffered fear, of course, but discipline has to overcome that to accomplish your mission.
What did you think of your commanding officer and the way that the unit was run, the quality of the officers in charge?
Well, we had a West Point Lieutenant Colonel commanding the battalion at that time.
He wasn't anything too great.
The executive officer was an ROTC graduate from Oklahoma State University named Alvin Mullenro.
I can't even remember the name of the West Point officer that commanded it, but he was wounded.
in the breakout up on this hill 192 where we had such a hell of a fight to get it back after we first had it with no resistance whatever and evacuated.
Why'd you evacuate this strategic location?
They were taken back to England.
They were taken to the beach and through medical evacuation taken back to England.
trips that were faring, ships that were faring troops over.
So we didn't think that is a general officer corps, we're not extremely respectful of that commander.
Al Mudrow
was, I'd have to say, some improvement.
It could be that, of course, nearly all of us in the battalion by that time had gotten commissions through ROTC, and I guess we were glad to see one of the ROTC graduates get in command.
Oh, he was a commander of the battalion for the rest of the
279 days that I was in combat.
I still see him occasionally.
He's moved from Oklahoma to Brownfield, Texas out west of Lubbock, and is a large farmer out there.
We respected him.
How can you continue the war after the hill and did you continue your sweep eastward?
Well at Hill 192, we had one heck of a fight getting that back.
It was highly fortified.
We were looking forward to getting that as an observation post to continue the attack, but when we did finally take it,
very ironical that it provided very good observation all the way back to Omaha Beach, but the observation to the south and east wasn't any good at all.
It was too heavily wooded on those slopes, so it really wasn't.
We had to rely on our light aviation for observation more.
Then we got diverted
All the way down, they sent three divisions down to try to take the port of Brest in southern France.
And this was, the Allies needed a seaport.
When was this?
Oh gosh, I don't know.
It must have been about August.
I think that was about eight weeks after we landed.

six weeks and right after Patton broke through he you know went around all down in southern France and just bottled up and bypassed German troops and assembled in several seaports along the way which was of course very good strategy for them because these seaports had great tactical importance at that time we were loading off loading all supplies just from temporary port facilities
So we needed a major C4.
I believe the high command believed that if we had a big show of force at Brest that the Germans would surrender.
But we got down there and got into a hell of a fight.
Very ironical that the only allied troops down around Brest when we got there with a whole corps, three divisions,
was one tank destroyer battalion.
That's all there were, didn't they?
Allied troops.
Well, instead of surrendering, the Germans were, we found out later, were under direct orders from Hitler to hold out till the death.
So we got in a tremendous fight and fought hard for a month before we took Brest.
And after Brest fell, it was not useful, never was used
Germans did a fantastic job of demolition of all the port facilities.
They used it and then destroyed it.
That's right.
You know they had vast submarine pans, reinforced concrete 15 feet thick or some fantastic amount that was really bomb proof.
Had railroad tunnels around where they were absolutely invulnerable to artillery fire and all.
very difficult to take this interior city of Brest.
And the...
Fairly high casualties.
The artillery had a tremendous amount to do because rather than frontal attacks on the fortress Brest, interior Brest, tremendous amount of artillery fire and bombing were used.
To sort of polarize them into submission?

Right, but finally there was finally there was street by street fighting to finally take breast and you know you couldn't go down the streets at all because the streets were commanded by German machine gun and artillery fire all the way down the streets.
So the infantry developed a new tactic
They used satchel charges to just blow holes through the walls of buildings, one building after another.
What kind of charges?
Satchel charges.
These are charges that are made up in like a little satchel that a person would use.
And they'd be put against the wall and lighted with a fuse.
And they are concentrated charges that blow a hole in a wall.
So the engineer troops did that.
so the infantry could progress down the interior of the blocks and didn't have to get exposed out on the streets.
So after Brest fell- Were there many German prisoners?
I believe that the prisoners were 55,000 taken out of there, so they had a tremendous number of troops in the fortress of Brest.
A lot of them were support troops and that's where we found out they had a good many women.
Men as old as 70 years old that were serving in the German army.
That early?
That old.
But I mean that early in the war I knew that Hitler committed a number of elderly people and a number of very young people, but I was under the opinion that that was like January of 45 and
and they had 70 year old men.
They were Germans or were they French?
They were German, but they were doing the support bit, the finance, the quartermaster, the support.
But you were surprised to see those people?
We were surprised, but still they had enough
fanatical SS troops around to make any of that kind of people fight.
Because they were more afraid of their own troops than they were of us.
Once they got committed to front lines, there's no question that the fanatical troops of the Germans kept them fighting.
Were you part then of taking the prisoners of war, or did you watch them march out, or how did that work?
Not directly.
Our artillery would be a little bit further down.
Of course we watched them march out, sure, but as far as being directly involved, our artillery battalion of general support nature was not that close.
Where were you?
Were you a couple of miles behind the infantry troops?
Yes.
In a sacred location?
Yes, of course always the artillery headquarters would be stationed beyond small arms fire front lines.
Of course now we don't talk very much about front lines, but in those days they were front lines fairly well established.
So they, we would tend to try to get the headquarters far enough back
to avoid vulnerability from small arms fire or mortar fire.
So usually they were a couple of miles at least.
And you wanted to be close enough so you could be called in.
Well, with a forward movement, of course you want to be stationed as far forward as you can to avoid having to displace any more than you have to.
We actually kept our headquarters in the same location for the whole month because we were within range of anywhere in that whole Brest city complex from the one position we occupied.
It was the strangest thing in the world that after Brest fell we were 800 miles from the front lines.
We turned on the lights.
It's just like being in the communication zone rather than in the combat zone.
We was far away.
So our next displacement was 800 miles clearing to Germany.
And when was that?
Was that before the Battle of the Bulge?
Oh, sure.
It was well before the Battle of the Bulge.
So it would have been in October, November, I'd say.
Or 44.
Probably late October because I believe we were at Lausfeld, Germany.
And we were occupying the positions which we occupied for about six weeks and were later displaced by the 106th Division.
Moved directly from Boston and replaced us position for position when we were pulled out.
and put into an attack on the Rohrer River dams.
Can you tell me about that?
Well, we had a very thin position in the Snee Eifel, the snow mountain area of Germany, considered to be an unlikely attack spot.
We were occupying 27,000 square miles, I mean 27,000 yards of front.
way overextended for an infantry division.
Some of, a lot of the territory was covered just by patrols, not any troops stationed in it at all.
And that's where the Germans hit on the Battle of the Bulge.
We had
just two or three days before, had been pulled out and committed on an attack on the Rohwer River dams to try to prevent the Germans from blowing those up and flooding the Rohwer River.
So in the Battle of the Bulge, the 106th Division that replaced us was captured almost intact.
It hit right through the positions where we were.
It's very strange that
Some of the activities we had observed and reported back, there seemed to be a lot of digging of potatoes and that sort of thing that we'd observed from our observation posts.
We know now, of course, and knew later, is Germans were removing their minefields and getting ready to attack.
There was a stretch of very bad weather, you see, during that covered the German massing of troops in their attack.

I always wonder whether a seasoned division like us would have been able to hold them because there was only one or two main roads coming into our whole division area, whether with artillery fire and with experienced resistance, whether we'd have been able to hold the attack right there.
Kind of like to believe that we could have, but anyhow,

The first we knew about it is that the first troops of our division that felt the attack was a quartermaster company of our division, so they came in and hit our division right in the rear, absolutely.
Our people at our airfield for our little Leber Cousins plane woke up one morning with the German tanks overlooking the field.
But it's very strange that the German tanks were committed without very much infantry.
And all of our aviation personnel were able to walk away from there without any of them getting captured.
Because the Germans didn't have infantry along with their tanks.
Is this because they were probably short of manpower?
I think they probably were.
But anyway, our
particular artillery battalion turned the guns 180 degrees around.
So we were attacking and so the threat was clear in the rear of the battalion.
And our howitzers were turned around 180 degrees and they were registered by the division artillery S3 looking out of his
third-story window in a building because the German troops got within one-half mile of our division headquarters, our division artillery headquarters, so our pouches were turned around.
You must have been under intense fire then, weren't you?
No, we really weren't.
The Germans never knew that that's where the division headquarters were.
They could easily have taken division headquarters or division artillery at that time, but we did not feel any of their fire at all.
They just passed you and just kept moving?
That's right.
You were sort of a pocket within their advance?
Actually our division
was on, as I recall, the northern side of the breakthrough area.
We're mighty proud of the fact that they never widened the breakthrough area at all.
Our division was attacked by five different German divisions as they would hit our division, but then displaced to the west.
So they displaced, gosh, I guess 100 miles to the west.
but they never widened that area, so they never got but one real main supply route.
So when the weather cleared, of course our Air Force really took care of their supply trains and all the vehicles they had along that main supply route.
And we think that we were part of the reason for that.
Our division got reinforced by a tank battalion that had been on
rest leave somewhere, was put right into a tank destroyer battalion, not tank battalion.
We had a tank destroyer battalion attached to our fire direction center.
Our ammunition train, going back to the ammunition dump, captured some German parachute troops.
They had a parachute troop landing
in support of this, but the high winds scattered them out and they never were able to assemble and become an effective fighting force.
So they hit in our rear area, but never created as much havoc.
The biggest threat we had during this time was German soldiers in American uniforms using American vehicles.
So this was a threat.
and all the confusion and everything.
And of course they soon learned the sign and countersign that we had where we'd challenge people.
With American ingenuity, they started asking them things like, who won the World Series?
Things like that that any American soldier would know, but the Germans wouldn't know.
the way some of them, of course many of them spoke just as good English as our troops.
That was a big threat, all right, posing as American soldiers, being German soldiers.
During this battle, our artillery, we darn near wore out our howitzers, and we really had a lot of artillery fire, and of course
Just before daylight every day, we would mass fire on all of the most logical assembly points.
Of course, artillery was a mighty big factor in this.
Then again, our experience- Especially before the weather cleared.
Yeah, and our experienced infantry troops in these little towns with the narrow streets were able to be in the basement of these towns.
And as I remember, one of our infantry regiments,

knocked out 68 German tanks just going down the streets of narrow town because they they could do it with bazooka fire with uh with satchel charges that sort of thing because of course a tank without infantry support the tankers are pretty blind and if you're in the basement of buildings on narrow streets where you sure have good shots of tanks but one of our
Infantry regiments really took care of a lot of those tanks just by themselves.
I'd say that was the most glorious contribution that the 2nd Infantry Division made in all of World War II, right there in the Battle of the Bulge.
Of course that was mid-December of 1944.
Were you and your colleagues pretty surprised about the German attack?
Did you think that the Germans were fairly well beat?
No, I don't think we had a very good perception of that.
We didn't know that much about the big picture.
The Germans we'd been up against all along the way were damn good fighters, so we had tremendous respect for them.
What do you mean they were excellent fighters?
In what way?
Well, they were well trained.
The individual soldiers were well disciplined, well trained, and many of them just absolutely fanatical.
They were skillful, had pretty darn good equipment.
Their 88 and their machine pistols were
tremendous weapons.
We had a lot of respect for them, sure.

We were very surprised about the attack through that particular area, because we'd been occupying those spots for a long time, and there'd been almost no activity, so it was considered to be a very quiet area of the front, an unlikely area for any kind of attack.
So I'd have to say that the German tactics in using that were superb.
